Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states and operations. However, this description is incomplete because it does not specify the mathematical structure of the states. In this paper, we provide a categorical description of quantum theory, in which the states are elements of a category of Hilbert spaces. This description is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. However, the evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, which reveals that myxozoans are cnidarians and that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasite was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results provide insights into the evolution of parasitic lifestyles and the origin of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that determine their pathogenicity. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) in order to impair their transcriptional induction. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. Climate change is expected to cause a reduction in crop yields in many regions of the world. However, the magnitude of the yield reduction is uncertain because of the lack of data on the relationship between temperature and crop yield. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from virtually zero to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. These results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We conclude that investments in breeding for heat tolerance are urgently needed.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a fundamental question in ecology. However, it is difficult to quantify because of the large number of species involved. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that the extent of diet overlap was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than between species that were dissimilar in these ways. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages. Our results also suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large mammal populations.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and many anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will be critical to the survival of many small businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load on the open ocean surface is far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris, which are mostly related to the fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller. This sink may involve a combination of fast fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the elements is one of the most fundamental questions in astronomy. The study of the chemical composition of the Solar System and its components is a key to understanding the evolution of the universe. The chemical composition of the Sun itself is a key to understanding the evolution of the universe. The Sun is a typical member of the Milky Way galaxy. The chemical composition of the Sun is a key to understanding the evolution of the Milky Way galaxy.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, with the motorized fleet increasing in size and importance. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing, or the provision of food to offspring. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in oligodendrocytes. This would have important implications for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It controls vascular function, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between blood and tissue. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate a huge amount of information from multiple sources. This information is used to control the function of the endothelium. The nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate this information is poorly understood. Here, we show that the communication system is a small-world network, which is a property of networks that allows rapid and robust communication between cells. This property is important for the control of vascular function. The findings have implications for our understanding of the control of blood pressure and inflammation. They also have implications for the design of new drugs that target the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor the pandemic and to inform public health policy. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the data that are available are often not in a common format. We describe the data sources and signals in the COVIDcast API, which is a publicly available data portal that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure. They are also involved in the transmission of nerve impulses. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of potassium ions. The activation gate is the part of the channel that opens and closes the channel. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a mechanical switch for the control of the channel’s gating. This work provides a structural basis for the control of the selectivity filter and its role in the gating of potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change over time. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host, and the host can influence the microbiome. The gut microbiome is also a source of natural products, which are compounds that are produced by microorganisms and have a range of biological activities. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products of anaerobic fungi, which are a group of gut microbes that have not been extensively studied. The results of this study provide a foundation for future research on the natural products of anaerobic fungi and other gut microbes.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. We show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of developing a subordinate social status, directly influences social dominance. We further identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in social behavior, in the establishment of social dominance. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and for the development of new treatment strategies for anxiety-related social disorders.

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired responses is critical for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of structures. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The synthesized structures are digitally designed to exhibit desired responses under large deformations. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture structures with complex responses. The developed synthesis, fabrication, and response realization strategy can be utilized to design and manufacture mechanical devices with specific responses for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is developmentally regulated, but the mechanisms underlying this regulation are not fully understood. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 expression is reduced in fetal liver and increased in adult bone marrow, and this developmental pattern is reflected in the hemoglobin expression profile of erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for the evolution of hemoglobin in vertebrates.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to current therapies. Thus, there is an urgent need to identify new therapeutic strategies. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that this resistance is mediated by mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which is highly frequent in cancer. We also identified a mechanism of ferroptosis induction in cancer cells, which can be used to overcome this resistance. Our findings have implications for the treatment of cancer and other diseases. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of heart failure. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring, and used adaptive management. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of this policy on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations. However, the policy failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, which are now accelerating. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a model for how science can be used to inform policy for biodiversity conservation. We hope that this study will help to ensure that the NWFP continues to be effective in the future. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We used computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome to screen acylide antibiotics. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and showed activity against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study demonstrates the potential of computational approaches to address the challenge of antibiotic resistance. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. The results of this study may contribute to the development of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become increasingly common. However, the biological effects of such technology use on sleep have not been well studied. Here we compare the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. We found that reading an LE-eBook phase-delayed the circadian clock, acutely suppressed melatonin, and reduced the next-morning alertness and performance. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also highlights the need for more research on the biological effects of light emitted by electronic devices. Such research is critical to understanding the impact of these devices on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Ytterby meteorite fell in Sweden in 1739 and provided the first evidence for the existence of meteorites. The Ytterby meteorite is a rare earth element (REE) chondrite, which is a class of meteorites that are thought to contain the most primitive material from which the solar system formed. The YDB is a boundary between two major stages of the Pleistocene glaciation. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope record of the YDB is consistent with the hypothesis of an impact.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system has been controversial, and its function in the periphery and in tolerance has not been fully elucidated. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the absence of which the disease is not fatal. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the periphery and in tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes, including those encoding microbial enzymes that are key to the digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved the evolutionary history of beetles and revealed that the origin of beetles and their plant-feeding habits coincide with the first appearance of genes encoding microbial enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These genes may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of beetles, which in turn may have led to the evolution of the most diverse group of animals.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection provided by vaccines and prior infection. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning approach to enhance the binding affinity of an antibody to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrated that our approach can improve the binding affinity of an antibody to multiple VOCs, including Delta, by ∼10- to 600-fold. Our results suggest that this approach can be used to engineer antibodies that can be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can also be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines, to improve their efficacy against emerging variants. This work provides a promising strategy for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology, the spread of ideas, and the development of human societies.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a ∼12-fold decreased risk. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,500 km in radius and has a temperature of about 6,000 K. It is the only solid core in the solar system. The formation of the inner core is one of the most important unsolved problems in geophysics. We demonstrate that the metastable, body-centered, cubic phase of iron has a much higher nucleation rate than does the stable, hexagonal, close-packed phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the Earth and other terrestrial planets. They also have implications for the formation of other solid cores in the solar system. They may also provide a new way to understand the formation of other solid cores in the solar system.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatment.

Language is a uniquely human ability. Despite its importance, how the human brain processes language is one of the most challenging problems in cognitive science. In this work, we use a powerful new class of computational models to make significant progress on this problem. We show that the models’ internal representations and parameters are strongly correlated with their ability to predict both the brain and behavior. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the language comprehension circuitry of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still not clear how to compute with DLs. We show that, for some problems, it is possible to compute with DLs, but only with a very large amount of data. This is a fundamental limitation of DLs, which is not present in other areas of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. This has led to a reexamination of a classic experiment that has been cited more than 10,000 times. The experiment’s design flaws were first identified in 1975 and have been repeatedly pointed out since. Yet, despite the flaws, the study is still widely used as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We discuss the flaws in the experiment’s design and how they led to the study’s conclusion. We also discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human cognition.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for different forms of the disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. We compared the genome with that of M. leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. Our results suggest that M. lepromatosis is a potential pathogen and that the two bacteria have retained many of the same functions despite their ancient separation. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy bacteria and may lead to the discovery of new targets for the development of new drugs. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two most difficult to study in quantum systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in a class of interacting quantum systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is integrable and thus allows for a complete solution. Our work opens the door to the study of entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in more than 500 million infections and over 6.3 million deaths worldwide. The development of vaccines is the only way to end the pandemic. However, the development of a vaccine is a long and expensive process. Therefore, it is important to identify alternative strategies to develop a vaccine. Here, we describe a strategy to develop a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. This strategy is based on the use of a temperature-sensitive virus.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the primary transmission pathway. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-to-human transmission in the history of plague.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of brain power. However, this approach is biased by the fact that the number of neurons is the fundamental unit of brain computation. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) in mitochondria has been the subject of intense investigation for the past 15 y. However, the function of TRAP1 in normal cells has been difficult to determine because of the lack of specific inhibitors of TRAP1. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that this mitochondrial chaperone may be a promising target for

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that can disassemble actin filaments. It is a key regulator of the cell’s cytoskeleton. We show that ADF can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We show that the mechanical state of the filament, such as its curvature or twist, can enhance or inhibit severing. We also show that the action of ADF can be enhanced by the mechanical state of the filament. This is a new mechanism that could be important for the function of ADF in cells.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Understanding the effects of different sugars on brain and behavior may help to reduce the consumption of fructose and its potential health consequences.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both regions. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data. We find that the settlement was recent, but the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the human population in other island settings. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a massive-scale form of emotional contagion, which is not dependent on in-person interaction or nonverbal cues. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not aware of those emotions. This work also suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not aware of those emotions.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a relatively new area of study. In this work, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. This study provides a foundation for further investigation of the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is meaningful and worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is associated with positive changes in outcomes over time. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) at 37 °C. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results have implications for understanding the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the nose and for developing strategies to combat the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. In this study, we show that the type IV pili of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the bacterial cell. This results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment to surfaces, which in turn can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are used by bacteria as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the cell, and provide insights into the evolution of bacterial mechanosensing. This is important for understanding the role of pili in bacterial motility and biofilm formation, and for developing new strategies to combat bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides should be reduced worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a free-living animal species that is susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human infections are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. A better understanding of the role of animals in the spread of SARS-CoV-2 is critical to mitigate the risk of future outbreaks. This study highlights the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of dams in the developing world, the impacts of dams, and the challenges of incorporating climate change into the decision-making process. We also propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein, which are toxic to neurons. However, the earliest pathological changes in AD are not associated with these proteins. We show that soluble Aβ, which is the most toxic amyloid species, is the primary driver of an early inflammatory response in the brain. This response is initiated by neurons, which are burdened with increasing levels of Aβ. Our findings have important implications for the development of new AD therapies. They suggest that targeting Aβ may not be sufficient to halt the progression of the disease, and that the development of new treatments to prevent the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be necessary. This may lead to the discovery of new therapeutic targets for AD. (Show more)

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for most proteins. The pathway is important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell, and it may be important for understanding the role of the mutation in the protein. We have developed a method to study the folding of a protein at high structural resolution. We have applied the method to maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to fold through a native-like intermediate. We have found that the intermediate is not the only step in the folding pathway. The pathway is more complex than previously thought. The results may help to understand the role of the protein in the cell. They may also help to understand the role of the mutation in the protein. (Read more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping Np4-capped RNAs. We also show that, unlike ApaH, RppH prefers to decape capped RNAs over their capped counterparts. This preference is due to the unconventional manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH, positioning the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack. The differential impact of RppH and ApaH on the rates at which capped and capped-capped RNAs are deprotected could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Although there are several treatments for sepsis, there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We found that citrulline, a dietary amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also highlight the importance of humans in the history of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and physics where systems can spontaneously reach a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of activity levels, which is a hallmark of criticality. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and other applications. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be made a conductor by applying strain. We also show that the bandgap of diamond can be made to change with strain. These findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for specific applications.

The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the role of fungal pathogens in the defense against plant immune system is less understood. Here, we show that a plant immune system-derived peptide, NCR044, can kill plant fungal pathogens. We show that the peptide binds to multiple phosphoinositides in vitro and in planta, and that it kills fungal pathogens by penetrating the fungal cell wall and causing leakage of the contents of the cytoplasm. This work provides a new insight into the role of plant fungal pathogens in the plant immune system. It also paves the way for development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and we identify a number of female-derived proteins that are associated with sperm. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping them stick to the vessel wall and stop bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding, which explains the pathophysiology of VWD. This mechanism is general and can be used to study the effects of mutations in other proteins. The results are important for understanding the role of VWF in hemostasis and for developing new therapies for VWD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. We find that viruses are associated with a wide range of diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models due to the complexity of the process. Observational capability is also limited. This study introduces a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome these challenges. The instrument is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. This instrument was used to conduct a case study over Beijing. The results show that the aerosol loading had no discernible effect on liquid water path but increased the cloud droplet number concentration and decreased the cloud droplet effective radius. These findings support the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The temperature of the early Earth has been estimated to be as high as 70 °C, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth today is only 15 °C. This difference has been attributed to a variety of factors, including the uncertainty of the isotopic record, the possibility of resetting of the isotopic record, and the depositional environment. We show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth was lower in the past than it is today.

K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 209 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This work has implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs and for understanding the role of biophysical properties in other biological systems. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and other applications. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are expected to advance the development of diamond-based devices. They also provide a general framework for strain engineering of other materials. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of interferon-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza epidemics and for developing strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the neural basis of the merge operation. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. The merge operation was implemented in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal sites, providing evidence for a neural implementation of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This hierarchical structure may be important for language comprehension and production.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated in the developing mouse embryo. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and this effect can be blocked by lesions of the dopamine system. Here we show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving the LH and the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), and that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. We also show that the LH circuit is involved in the overeating that is characteristic of obesity. This work provides a more complete understanding of the brain circuitry that regulates feeding. It may also lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is the major factor limiting crop yields. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture has the potential to increase crop yields, but the bacteria must be able to fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. We have developed a system that allows us to control the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in association with the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to develop a sustainable source of nitrogen for agriculture. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. We show that the spider web is a new type of hearing organ that is not constrained by the body. The web is a highly sensitive acoustic antenna that can detect the motion of the air particles. The spider can remotely sense the direction and location of the sound source. The web can be easily regenerated, and the spider can adjust the size of the web to meet its needs. This provides a unique way to study the sensing of air flow and to design acoustic flow detectors.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a global effort is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This would be a major step toward a sustainable future.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health. The development of vaccines is a critical step in containing the pandemic. We report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD that is well-suited for large-scale production. This engineered RBD can be expressed in a variety of expression systems, including bacteria, yeast, and mammalian cells. The engineered RBD can also be presented on a VLP, which may further enhance the immunogenicity of the vaccine. This engineered RBD may provide a cost-effective and scalable vaccine platform for the global fight against COVID-19.

The role of the ALK receptor in development is well established. However, the ligand(s) that activate ALK in vivo are unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like (DrALK) are ligands for DrALKals. We further show that DrALKals are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK in development and suggest a role for ALKALs in the regulation of neural crest development.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for some of the most devastating outbreaks in human history. However, our knowledge of its early evolution and ecology is limited. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the diversity of this pathogen during its formative years. We find that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague was nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct by the time of the Bronze Age. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) is a key component of soil quality and a critical resource for the global food supply. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of SOC. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on SOC storage and distribution remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate legumes and manure into annual cropping systems can increase SOC and particulate organic carbon in the top 15 cm of soil. However, these practices did not increase mineral-associated organic carbon, which is the most stable fraction of SOC. These results highlight the key role of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We used this framework to rank 887 viruses, including 12 that have not previously been linked to disease outbreaks. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. This work provides a blueprint for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of tools to prioritize and manage them.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to their pollinators. The color of this reward is often a key factor in attracting pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a similar trait in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is a convergent adaptation, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in attracting pollinators. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from the late 5th/early 6th century Europe. We show that women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, which includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the absence of a template. This process is essential for the synthesis of the Okazaki fragments of the lagging strand. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the synthesis of the lagging strand. However, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme has not been measured. Here, we developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is stable and maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp. Such behavior has profound implications for lagging strand synthesis in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the replication of genetic information was accomplished by RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA can replicate itself, but it has been difficult to improve the activity of the RNA polymerases that are required for the replication of genetic information. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase that can replicate a variety of RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world in the laboratory. It also provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, which can reduce mortality and improve the clinical condition.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a variety of mechanisms to maintain copper homeostasis. We report the discovery of a copper-binding metabolite of the xan BGC, a gene cluster that is widespread in filamentous fungi. The xan BGC is expressed in A. fumigatus in response to copper limitation, and the xan BGC isocyanide is secreted and has antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC isocyanide is a novel fungal natural product that has a role in copper homeostasis and in interactions with competing microbes. This study demonstrates the existence of a previously unknown role for fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors of plants and animals, but despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is different in different regions. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. In addition, our findings suggest that the development of Th17 cells may be a useful target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells are toxic to motor neurons, a hallmark of ALS. We show that this toxicity is due to the presence of the ALS-associated superoxide dismutase or C9orf72 expansion. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies for ALS. This study will also help to understand the role of astrocytes in ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. However, the mechanisms by which Anaplasma influences the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. We also show that antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors. Such knowledge is critical for understanding the ecology of vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle). However, the known diversity of early members of the group of birds with a short tail is limited, making it difficult to understand the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we report a new basal member of the group with a short tail, which adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to climate change. This is a major change in perspective, as the stratosphere has been considered a relatively stable region of the atmosphere. We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to climate change, and that it is important to include the stratosphere in climate models.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In many species, the color of their tissues and bones is determined by the concentration of a pigment called biliverdin. In this study, we show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most diverse group of proteins that inhibit proteases. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is common in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a serpin in vertebrates. This study also provides a unique example of how a serpin can bind a pigment that is not a protein.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells have the capacity to form cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of pluripotency factor NANOG and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways. ALKBH5 expression is required for the induction of NANOG expression by hypoxia. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression mediates enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. These findings have implications for the treatment of breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily damaged. This study shows that the animal from which the parchment was made was not a secret.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a critical control on the timing of the carbon cycle perturbation, which is a key trigger of the extinction. The age of the extinction is also critical for evaluating the timing of ecosystem recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates of volcanic ash beds. The age model is consistent with the carbon cycle perturbation, and the timing of ecosystem recovery. The age model will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.
