The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human ACE2 receptor. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has resulted in a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. Our results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein. This information will be useful for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a significant improvement over the previous best result, which only holds for games with finitely many periods. Our result is also more general, as it applies to games with infinitely many periods.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, compared with the actual value of 77.48 y. We also project that life expectancy at age 65 y would have been 89.2 y, compared with the actual value of 89.9 y. These projections imply that, in the absence of the pandemic, the Black−White life expectancy gap would have been 5.4 y, compared with the actual value of 3.6 y. These projections suggest that the pandemic has widened the gap between Whites and Blacks, and Latinos, and that the gap between Whites and Latinos has narrowed. These projections are based on the assumption that the pandemic would have had no impact on life expectancy.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that both properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these effects is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, rather than climate, is the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming, although the magnitude of the effect is uncertain. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need for more research on the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major component of the immune system, and its composition is known to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiota is regulated are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the composition of the gut microbiota in a way that is likely to be important for the health of the host.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify the topics that are present in a corpus. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in the narratives of the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the narratives contain many topics that are not captured by the structured variables of the system. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gender bias of the topics is consistent with known biases in semantic space. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many types of text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were strongly correlated, and that this was the main driver of the reintroduction of plague into Europe. Our results suggest that the climate was the main factor in the spread of the disease, and that the introduction of the bacterium into Europe was not a singular event. This is important for the understanding of the epidemiology of the plague, and for the interpretation of the history of the second plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a group of organisms that have been studied for more than 200 y. They are characterized by a lack of a hard exoskeleton and a complex life cycle. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of at least 20 species of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is spread by plankton. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also find that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, but the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. Finally, we show that a few centuries are enough to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection provided by vaccines and prior infection. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning approach to enhance the binding affinity of an antibody to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrated that our approach can improve the binding affinity of an antibody to multiple VOCs, including Delta, by ∼10- to 600-fold. Our results suggest that this approach can be used to develop new antibody drug candidates that can be used to combat emerging variants. This approach can also be extended to other protein molecules, such as vaccines, to improve their efficacy against variants. Overall, this work highlights the potential of deep learning in the development of new therapeutics for COVID-19.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative applications. We show how to convert the original crop expert assessments into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used in quantitative applications. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by developing a quantitative crop condition index that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The index can be easily adapted to other crops and countries.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, this view is challenged by evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may also play a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains unclear. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, totaling over 3,800 observations. Our analysis reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with experimental warming in most biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. This lack of warming-induced acclimation of soil respiration in many biomes is consistent with the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results suggest that soil respiration may not be a major driver of global warming, but rather a more sensitive indicator of local climate conditions.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major evolutionary event that has shaped the molecular evolution of the plastid genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolution of the plastid genome is a dynamic process that is shaped by the evolutionary history of the host. This model can be applied to other evolutionary transitions that shape the molecular evolution of the genome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of human influence on recent climate change. However, the results are based on a single case study, and the findings should be replicated in other regions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a naturally occurring icosahedral quasicrystal in red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material, which was formed in the seconds after the first nuclear explosion, provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals form. This discovery also demonstrates that the synthesis of quasicrystals is possible in the laboratory, and that the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems is possible in the field.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that is used by all life. The chlorophyll pigments are the key intermediates in this process. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, is the most important reaction in this pathway. This ring is essential for the capture of solar energy and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of this ring has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of this reaction and its three classes. These data are important for understanding the evolution of photosynthesis. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may also provide insights into the pathophysiology of neuroinflammation in MS. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought years has increased because of the occurrence of warm conditions. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and wildfire risk in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a unique example of how a simple behavioral assay can be used to identify a common mechanism underlying the effects of multiple autism-risk genes. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, but they also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. This variation is likely to be important for understanding the prevalence of negativity biases in human cognition and behavior, and for understanding the news content that people around the world consume.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which cause congenital bleeding and myopathy. Our data suggest that the CRAC channel can be regulated by mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which may be a common mechanism in patients with Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, showing that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of neurodegenerative disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats. This protein, which we named Myotis pilosus toxin (MTX), selectively inhibits the function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase, which is responsible for the hydrolysis of leukotriene A4 to leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases and maintained high stability, which facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic processes that supports cell growth is the conversion of serine into glycine and a folate-dependent one-carbon unit. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and have shown that it blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also shown that the cancer cell-line screen that led to this discovery identified B-cell lines as particularly sensitive to the inhibitor. This sensitivity is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a common feature of B-cell malignancies. Thus, we have identified a targetable metabolic deficiency of B-cell lymphoma. This work has implications for the treatment of cancer and B-cell malignancies. It also provides a model for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of other enzymes that convert one-carbon units. This latter class of enzymes is important in many metabolic processes, and thus represents a promising area of drug discovery.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that ALS is a disease of protein misfolding and aggregation, and that the inclusion bodies are a natural consequence of the disease process. This may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The band structures of the photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to have a broad impact on the field of atom optics and many-body physics. It is also expected to have a significant impact on the field of photonic crystals, which are used in many applications, including optical data storage and optical computing.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. Here, we present a detailed analysis of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous that is the earliest known flowering plant. Our analysis suggests that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that is similar to Montsechia in morphology and reproduction. Montsechia is also very old, suggesting that aquatic habitats may have been common at an early stage of flowering plant evolution.

The evolution of viruses is a key component of the history of life on Earth. However, the evolution of viruses is difficult to study because of their small size and the difficulty of obtaining viral sequences from ancient remains. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human pathogen parvovirus B19 has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. These results are important for our understanding of the evolution of viruses and the history of life. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily for decades. This rise is due to a combination of natural processes and human activities. We show that the acceleration of sea level over the last 25 y is due to human activities. We also show that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. These results are important for understanding the causes of sea level rise and for planning for the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that pain has increased more for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate of tryptophan synthase with indole, a reaction that is central to the mechanism of this enzyme. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed picture of the reaction of a stable enzyme intermediate. This approach can be applied to a wide range of enzymes and reaction types, and will be of particular value in the study of reactions that are difficult to study by other methods. This work also highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide insight into the role of water in enzyme catalysis. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the disease has a high case fatality rate. We tested the efficacy of the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir was highly effective in preventing disease, and in reducing the severity of disease that did occur. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing global pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major component of the immune system, and its composition is shaped by the host’s diet and the environment of the gut. In this study, we show that the symbiotic bacteria of a squid are maintained by the host only at night, when the host secretes a glycan that is catabolized by the bacteria. This glycan is provided at a specific time of day, when the squid is in its most immune-active state. This study suggests that the provision of specific nutrients by the host may be a common mechanism for regulating the activities of the gut microbiota.

This paper reports on a series of experiments and a field trial that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, with 31 teachers and 1,682 students. The intervention halved year-long suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This paper is a contribution to the growing literature on the importance of teachers’ mindsets and the potential for scalable interventions to change them.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on transcription. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also found that the three EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional error patterns. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II that is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This study also provides a comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms of transcription. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new strategies for cancer treatment. This study will also provide a foundation for the development of new strategies for cancer treatment.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease in humans. The virus infects human lung cells, but not other cell types, and therefore may be more virulent in humans than its relative, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). We found that the first proteolytic steps in MERS-CoV infection are important for virus tropism and for the virus’s virulence. These findings may help to explain why MERS-CoV is more virulent in humans than SARS-CoV.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in the food system could have a large impact on greenhouse gas emissions and obesity. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in many countries.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We apply quantitative proteomics to show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for expanding voting-by-mail programs in the United States. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been well studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is not a panacea for the problems of voter turnout. Rather, it is a tool that can be used to improve the electoral process.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic. The role of the ORF8 protein in the virus is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the ORF8 protein from SARS-CoV-2. We show that the structure is similar to that of ORF7a from SARS-CoV, but with a unique dimerization interface. This suggests that the structure may be important for the function of the protein.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using transfected cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to miss any. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in some common statistical methods.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, such as atherosclerosis and stroke. Therefore, the generation of ECs is a promising therapeutic approach for these disorders. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and may lead to the development of new therapies for vascular disorders. (Show more)

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in the development and the growth of many types of cancer. In the last few years, two new ligands for RTKs have been discovered. These ligands are important for the development of zebrafish pigment cells. Here, we show that these ligands are important for the development of zebrafish pigment cells and that they are important for the growth of cancer cells. These findings establish a link between the development of zebrafish pigment cells and cancer.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular bases of T2D are well known, the mechanisms underlying the development of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be elucidated. Here, we show that STING, a cytosolic sensor of double-stranded RNA, is required for the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also show that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data provide a possible mechanism for the development of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction in T2D and establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The evolution of these lineages is not well understood. Here, we show that the interaction between two viral RNA segments is sequence specific and that it is required for the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the development of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of these lesions is associated with the activation of atheroprone phenotypes in the vascular endothelium. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. En face analysis of mouse arteries demonstrated an increased nuclear localization of YAP/TAZ and elevated levels of the target genes in the endothelium in atheroprone areas compared with athero-protective areas. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major cause of ecosystem degradation. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity. However, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly approach to pest control. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, which should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the arthropod–plant adaptation. This study is also a contribution to the conservation of biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne pathogen that has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV infection and disease are not fully understood. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to reproduce the main features of the disease, including the presence of an eclipse phase, the rapid production of large amounts of virus by infected cells, and the short lifetime of infected cells while producing virus. We also show that a drug that blocks viral replication can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the timing of treatment is critical, and treatment given too late is mostly ineffective. These results can be used to guide the development of effective treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major stressor of coral reefs worldwide. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host is increased, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that separates the host from the external environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the spread of cancer cells into the body. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor model can be used to study the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium. We find that the tumor model leads to a dysbiotic microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response that stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in the regulation of the intestinal epithelium and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most important events in the Earth system, but the cause is still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a climate response. This is a unique and unexpected link between volcanism and climate, and it has important implications for our understanding of the causes of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are promising for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the CNS may be more robust than previously thought.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of meiosis. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in the population of cells that make up an organism. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a fundamental property of the genome that is important for understanding the evolution of the genome and the function of the genes it contains.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive functions. The present study provides a detailed description of the resting state organization of the brain, based on metabolic imaging. The results show that the default mode network is the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects, but is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. This finding has implications for the understanding of the functional significance of the default mode network in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In this study, we report the discovery of a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap in yeast. We also show that this cap is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This discovery expands the number of cap structures in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that this cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon that the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications persist for many years after the discontinuation of intensive therapy. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist in blood cells from people with diabetes for several years after discontinuation of intensive therapy. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells impairs proliferation and invasion and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The mechanisms underlying the development of this disorder are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for other psychiatric disorders.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a specific nitrogenous compound, 2-isobutylthiazole, which is a precursor for a large number of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these two factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming in conservation and management strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for spatial cognition. It contains a large number of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the spatial organization of these neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the spatial organization of place cells is different from that of other neurons in MEC. These data provide a detailed view of the spatial organization of neurons in MEC and will be useful for understanding the function of this important brain structure.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of regulation of flowering and may be a common feature of parasitic plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta and with the loss of nigral innervation of the striatum. Here, we describe a previously unidentified system within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is affected in the disease. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons in this system are located in striosomes and that they form specialized integrative units within the system. These findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the dopamine systems in health and disease. They also suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets could be a target for therapeutic intervention.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the way we read minds is by looking at the speed at which they respond to us.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for generating the heart rate and are therefore critical for the regulation of heart rate. SAN cells are also the only cells in the heart that have the ability to generate action potentials. The SAN is therefore a unique and important target for the treatment of heart failure. However, the mechanisms that regulate SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. Our studies reveal that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cells of the SAN and that its deletion in mice leads to a reduction in the number of Ca2+ stores in these cells. These studies provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN automaticity and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of allene oxide synthase or CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1. This interaction between Si and JA was associated with increased JA levels, enhanced expression of JA-responsive genes, and increased activity of defense enzymes. These results suggest that Si may promote plant resistance against insect herbivores by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides a new perspective on the function of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of lipid metabolism in macrophages.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms that are dependent on external inputs for their growth and development. One of the major challenges in plant biology is the delivery of biomolecules to plants, which is essential for the growth and development of plants. Here, we report the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for the study of plant biology and for the development of plant biotechnology.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, little is known about the nutrient inputs from small watersheds. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our findings reveal that small watersheds can be important sources of nutrients to coastal areas. This study highlights the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and provides a framework for understanding and managing nutrient inputs to lakes and coastal ecosystems. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles in a confining potential.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoimmune encephalitis that can cause a wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. However, the mechanisms underlying these paroxysms are poorly understood. Here, we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic properties of the brain, which can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are sufficient to induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. This work may help in the development of new therapies for this devastating disease. The history of abrupt climate change is critical to understanding the Earth system and its response to external forcing. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the lack of data and models that can resolve the short-term response of the system. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was driven by an increase in atmospheric CO2. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the potential for future climate change. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in the model organisms. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is one of the most fundamental aspects of animal biology. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this paper, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination genes in a species with four possible sex classes. We find that the interplay of sex determination genes in M. mbenjii produces modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that is a mixture of oxidized proteins and lipids. The oxidation of lipofuscin is a consequence of the high levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated in the retina. We show that the levels of the yellow pigment lipofuscin are reduced in mice treated with a chelator of iron, which is a component of lipofuscin. We also show that the levels of the yellow pigment are reduced in mice with increased levels of iron in the retina. These findings suggest that the levels of iron in the retina may regulate the levels of lipofuscin. This interpretation is supported by experiments showing that the levels of iron in the retina can be reduced by a chelator of iron, and that the levels of iron in the retina can be increased by a deficiency in the proteins that export iron from the retina. These findings have implications for understanding the role of iron in the retina. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the diversity of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the diversity of their prey. However, the evolution of predatory specialization has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved a modularity of their tentacles, which are used for prey capture. Our results show that this modularity is strongly associated with prey type, and suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentacles and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure with many derived features that are shared with Neandertals and modern humans. These features are not present in early hominin fossils, and the timing of their evolution is poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a feature that is present in modern humans and Neandertals but not in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic processes that supports cell growth is the conversion of serine into glycine and a folate-derived one-carbon unit. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a series of small molecules that inhibit both human SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in cell-based assays, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell cancer cell lines. We also show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity. These findings have implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the use of formate as a rescue of SHMT inhibition in other diseases. They also have implications for the use of formate as a one-carbon donor in metabolic engineering.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural habitats is a major threat to biodiversity. However, little is known about the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of forests. Our findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern agriculture is a major driver of global land use, with the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the use of farm machinery has come at a cost of soil compaction, which has been shown to reduce soil productivity. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a global increase in subsoil compaction, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend may have been a major driver of the decline of the sauropods, and that the roaming of these giants may have been a key ecological strategy for reducing subsoil compaction.
